message.raw:
Fixed a bug where labconfig would attempt to create the default section
if it does not exist. ConfigParser would not list it in existing sections, and then
throw an exception on attempting to create it, because it is treated specially.
Solution is to special case 'DEFAULT' and not attempt to create.
message.html:
Fixed a bug where labconfig would attempt to create the default section
if it does not exist. ConfigParser would not list it in existing sections, and then
throw an exception on attempting to create it, because it is treated specially.
Solution is to special case 'DEFAULT' and not attempt to create.

summary.raw:

throw an exception on attempting to create it, because it is treated specially.
Solution is to special case 'DEFAULT' and not attempt to create.

values.message:
Fixed a bug where labconfig would attempt to create the default section
if it does not exist. ConfigParser would not list it in existing sections, and then
throw an exception on attempting to create it, because it is treated specially.
Solution is to special case 'DEFAULT' and not attempt to create.

message.raw:
Fixed a regression introduced where the winshell module relied on the labscript
suite being installed.

All I needed was a unique string identifying the installation. Now, if there is
no installation, this is set to <not_installed>, rather than throwing an
exception.

This is just used for setting the AppIDs. It is useful for them to
be unique across installations, as otherwise windows can be slow to update
some sort of cache and taskbar behaviour can be wrong until it does so.
message.html:

exception.

This is just used for setting the AppIDs. It is useful for them to
be unique across installations, as otherwise windows can be slow to update
some sort of cache and taskbar behaviour can be wrong until it does so.

behave more predictably when installing and uninstalling apps repeatedly.

message.raw:
labonfig now looks in labscript install directory first before hardcoded
paths.

Fixed a bug in h5_lock where it would start zlock server in the current
working directory. On Windows, this would prevent deletion of that directory
later, as zlock would still be running and Windows won't let you delete folders
that are the working directory of a process. It now starts in %temp%.
message.html:
labonfig now looks in labscript install directory first before hardcoded
paths.

Fixed a bug in h5_lock where it would start zlock server in the current
working directory. On Windows, this would prevent deletion of that directory
later, as zlock would still be running and Windows won't let you delete folders
that are the working directory of a process. It now starts in %temp%.

values.message:
labonfig now looks in labscript install directory first before hardcoded

Fixed a bug in h5_lock where it would start zlock server in the current
working directory. On Windows, this would prevent deletion of that directory
later, as zlock would still be running and Windows won't let you delete folders
that are the working directory of a process. It now starts in %temp%.

message.raw:
Added remove_from_start_menu function, and pushed some app configuration into
the winshell module rather than in the app module itself, so the installer
can use it without having to import the app module.

message.raw:
fixed bug where newly spawned zlock server (spawned by h5_lock) would not
continue running after its parent died. Zlock persisting was intended
behaviour, this appears to be fixed now on Windows. Requires testing on linux.

message.raw:
Fixed bug where custom right-click menu of analog spin widget would not show in PyQt.

This was because in PyQt, you need to hold onto a reference to the menu object, or else it is garbage collected. In PySide, you do not. Introduced reference to the QMenu held by Python, is released when the menu is hidden.
message.html:
Fixed bug where custom right-click menu of analog spin widget would not show in PyQt.

This was because in PyQt, you need to hold onto a reference to the menu object, or else it is garbage collected. In PySide, you do not. Introduced reference to the QMenu held by Python, is released when the menu is hidden.

values.message:
Fixed bug where custom right-click menu of analog spin widget would not show in PyQt.

This was because in PyQt, you need to hold onto a reference to the menu object, or else it is garbage collected. In PySide, you do not. Introduced reference to the QMenu held by Python, is released when the menu is hidden.

message.raw:
Made some PyQt compatible changes.

* Forced unit from combobox to always be a Python string
* If evaluation of saved settings fails, print a warning error (this is likely because you are saving a PyQt or PySide specific enum, rather than converting to a nice ASCII representation.

Made some PyQt compatible changes.

  • Forced unit from combobox to always be a Python string
  • If evaluation of saved settings fails, print a warning error (this is likely because you are saving a PyQt or PySide specific enum, rather than converting to a nice ASCII representation.

message.raw:
Excepthook now doesn't raise errors during interpreter shutdown.
These are usually spurious - excepthook simply raises as normal and lets the
threading module deal with it in the usual way.

Also added python3 support fot excepthook, though labscript will not use this anywhere.
This is because I'm planning on realeasing excepthook as a standalone module at some point.

Bumped version to 1.0.4.

This is because I'm planning on realeasing excepthook as a standalone module at some point.

Bumped version to 1.0.4.

message.raw:
Improved invoke_in_main to *not* require my special QThread

inmain/inmain_later now pass the function to be run to a QThread over a Queue. This QThread posts the event back to the main thread using the inbuilt signal mechanism that do not leak memory.

This now implemets identical functionality to changeset:b1dd4a1a1c45 without the memory leak caused by postEvent

message.raw:
Bug Fixes + Class Rename

* Fixed a bug where inmain_later would not run in the main thread.
* Renamed InMainThread to EventPostingThread
* created a wrapper function to create the EventPostingThread and start it (this function is imported when you import qtutils, the class EventPostingThread is not)

message.raw:
Fixed many bugs in dragdroptab (perhaps oneday I'll rewrite it with the knowledge I've gained in the last 11 months!)

* Fixed issue where setting the current index (during tab focus restore) was not actually causing the tab to become active
* Switched some event processing to use QCoreApplication.postEvent rather than just calling the function directly
* Fixed the mimeData for our drag event to be custom, so that you can't drag a device tab into the hostname text box of the camera tab (for example)
* Fixed a bug where dragging a device tab (that was the sole tab in a notebook) to another notebook, and back again, would cause the tab to disappear (self.havent_left_source_tab code was being incorrectly reset, and other code was only running if it was False)
* Fixed an issue with incorrect tab label being highlighted (or no tab being highlighted at all)
* Stopped the flickering of the tab label when re-ordering the tab after moving to another notebook.
* Fixed an issue where we weren't re-adding the tab to it's original location if it didn't have a parent notebook unless the drag/drop was rejected by the target. It now doesn't matter if the drag was accepted or rejected by the target, if the dragged tab is in no-mans-land, it should go back to where it started from (hopefully!)
message.html:
Fixed many bugs in dragdroptab (perhaps oneday I'll rewrite it with the knowledge I've gained in the last 11 months!)

  • Fixed issue where setting the current index (during tab focus restore) was not actually causing the tab to become active
  • Switched some event processing to use QCoreApplication.postEvent rather than just calling the function directly
  • Fixed the mimeData for our drag event to be custom, so that you can't drag a device tab into the hostname text box of the camera tab (for example)
  • Fixed a bug where dragging a device tab (that was the sole tab in a notebook) to another notebook, and back again, would cause the tab to disappear (self.havent_left_source_tab code was being incorrectly reset, and other code was only running if it was False)
  • Fixed an issue with incorrect tab label being highlighted (or no tab being highlighted at all)
  • Stopped the flickering of the tab label when re-ordering the tab after moving to another notebook.
  • Fixed an issue where we weren't re-adding the tab to it's original location if it didn't have a parent notebook unless the drag/drop was rejected by the target. It now doesn't matter if the drag was accepted or rejected by the target, if the dragged tab is in no-mans-land, it should go back to where it started from (hopefully!)

summary.html:
Fixed many bugs in dragdroptab (perhaps oneday I'll rewrite it with the knowledge I've gained in the last 11 months!)

  • Fixed issue where setting the current index (during tab focus restore) was not actually causing the tab to become active
  • Switched some event processing to use QCoreApplication.postEvent rather than just calling the function directly
  • Fixed the mimeData for our drag event to be custom, so that you can't drag a device tab into the hostname text box of the camera tab (for example)
  • Fixed a bug where dragging a device tab (that was the sole tab in a notebook) to another notebook, and back again, would cause the tab to disappear (self.havent_left_source_tab code was being incorrectly reset, and other code was only running if it was False)
  • Fixed an issue with incorrect tab label being highlighted (or no tab being highlighted at all)
  • Stopped the flickering of the tab label when re-ordering the tab after moving to another notebook.
  • Fixed an issue where we weren't re-adding the tab to it's original location if it didn't have a parent notebook unless the drag/drop was rejected by the target. It now doesn't matter if the drag was accepted or rejected by the target, if the dragged tab is in no-mans-land, it should go back to where it started from (hopefully!)

values.message:
Fixed many bugs in dragdroptab (perhaps oneday I'll rewrite it with the knowledge I've gained in the last 11 months!)

* Fixed issue where setting the current index (during tab focus restore) was not actually causing the tab to become active
* Switched some event processing to use QCoreApplication.postEvent rather than just calling the function directly
* Fixed the mimeData for our drag event to be custom, so that you can't drag a device tab into the hostname text box of the camera tab (for example)
* Fixed a bug where dragging a device tab (that was the sole tab in a notebook) to another notebook, and back again, would cause the tab to disappear (self.havent_left_source_tab code was being incorrectly reset, and other code was only running if it was False)
* Fixed an issue with incorrect tab label being highlighted (or no tab being highlighted at all)
* Stopped the flickering of the tab label when re-ordering the tab after moving to another notebook.
* Fixed an issue where we weren't re-adding the tab to it's original location if it didn't have a parent notebook unless the drag/drop was rejected by the target. It now doesn't matter if the drag was accepted or rejected by the target, if the dragged tab is in no-mans-land, it should go back to where it started from (hopefully!)

message.raw:
Fixed inmain_later needing an extra argument after the changes inplemented in changeset:65d006d40bf3

If you wish to not have exceptions raised in the main thread when calling inmain_later, either use the function decorator, or call in_main_later (note the extra underscore in between 'in' and 'main'. Also note that you must specifically import the new in_main_later function using `from qtutils.invoke_in_main import in_main_later`. This is because I don't want people accidentally using the wrong one due to their similar names)

Perhaps a better naming scheme will be developed one day!

message.raw:
Modified invoke_in_main to not "leak" memory

I put "leak" in quotes because it is yet unclear whether it actually does leak memory. What we do know is that the memory usage of a program using the in_main function does grow, but periodically it drops significantly. Longer testing must be done before we can tell whether we actually have a memory leak.

However, I have discovered that the Qt documentation states that an event passed to QCoreApplication.postEvent() should not be accessed after it is posted. We were accessing it to wait for the event to be processed. When we don't access it after calling QCoreApplication.postEvent() (and instead pass in a queue at event instantiation, which we then wait on), the memory usage does not grow nearly as rapidly and from preliminary observations, oscialltes around an average usage.

Further testing will ensue.

However, I have discovered that the Qt documentation states that an event passed to QCoreApplication.postEvent() should not be accessed after it is posted. When we don't access it after calling QCoreApplication.postEvent() (and instead pass in a queue at event instantiation, which we then wait on), the memory usage does not grow nearly as rapidly and from preliminary observations, oscialltes around an average usage.

Further testing will ensue.

Modified invoke_in_main to not "leak" memory

I put "leak" in quotes because it is yet unclear whether it actually does leak memory. What we do know is that the memory usage of a program using the in_main function does grow, but periodically it drops significantly. Longer testing must be done before we can tell whether we actually have a memory leak.

However, I have discovered that the Qt documentation states that an event passed to QCoreApplication.postEvent() should not be accessed after it is posted. We were accessing it to wait for the event to be processed. When we don't access it after calling QCoreApplication.postEvent() (and instead pass in a queue at event instantiation, which we then wait on), the memory usage does not grow nearly as rapidly and from preliminary observations, oscialltes around an average usage.

Further testing will ensue.

message.raw:
Added a unit option to set_spinbox_value so that you don't get bad values shown on the front panel when a call to AO.set_value specifies a different unit.
A complementary change has been made to BLACS outputclasses. Make sure you update that as well!

message.raw:
Fixed a bug in previous commit.

Threads waiting on the result would hang if an exception was raised.
Now they are notified of the fucntion finishing (as normal)

message.raw:
A fix to ensure that exceptions do not pass silently

functions delegated to the main thread with inmain_later now will raise exceptions
in the main thread if wait() has not been called on their events
(ie if no thread is listening on the result, and therefore no thread will otherwise raise the exception).
message.html:
A fix to ensure that exceptions do not pass silently

functions delegated to the main thread with inmain_later now will raise exceptions
in the main thread if wait() has not been called on their events
(ie if no thread is listening on the result, and therefore no thread will otherwise raise the exception).

message.raw:
Rewrote the UiLoader class to be far better than the code I found on the internet

You can now promote widgets at runtime!
It is now much more general, and can apply to widgets beyond just the toplevel widget

As such there is now no trace of the code from the internet, so I'm relicensing this under the two-clause BSD as the rest of our work is.
message.html:
Rewrote the UiLoader class to be far better than the code I found on the internet

You can now promote widgets at runtime!
It is now much more general, and can apply to widgets beyond just the toplevel widget

As such there is now no trace of the code from the internet, so I'm relicensing this under the two-clause BSD as the rest of our work is.

You can now promote widgets at runtime!
It is now much more general, and can apply to widgets beyond just the toplevel widget

As such there is now no trace of the code from the internet, so I'm relicensing this under the two-clause BSD as the rest of our work is.
summary.html:
Rewrote the UiLoader class to be far better than the code I found on the internet

You can now promote widgets at runtime!
It is now much more general, and can apply to widgets beyond just the toplevel widget

As such there is now no trace of the code from the internet, so I'm relicensing this under the two-clause BSD as the rest of our work is.

values.message:
Rewrote the UiLoader class to be far better than the code I found on the internet

You can now promote widgets at runtime!
It is now much more general, and can apply to widgets beyond just the toplevel widget

As such there is now no trace of the code from the internet, so I'm relicensing this under the two-clause BSD as the rest of our work is.

message.raw:
Removed unnecessary code

confirmed that my implementation of custom widget promotion is working. This fixes the apparently broken implementation of QUiLoader.registerCustomWidget() in PySide (see http://lists.qt-project.org/pipermail/pyside/2012-May/000322.html) in a transparent way.

confirmed that my implementation of custom widget promotion is working. This fixes the apparently broken implementation of QUiLoader.registerCustomWidget() in PySide (see http://lists.qt-project.org/pipermail/pyside/2012-May/000322.html) in a transparent way.

message.raw:
Attempted to add support for custom widget promotion.

It seems to at least partially work (__init__ method of my promoted widget class is called). May be bugs I haven't found yet though

message.raw:
Adding fingertabs code (taken with permission from github user LegoStormtroopr)
Code is licensed under "Public Domain", and is credited to LegoStormtrropr accordingly

This code provides horizontal tabs on the left hand side of a TabWidget and will be used in BLACS the BLACS settinsg menu and main part of the runmanager interface (and possibly others in the future)

message.raw:
Added some code (that I got from the internet, it is licensed under the MIT license) that modifies the behaviour of the QUiLoader

This code allows you to create the "QMainWindow" in Qt Designer, but override the QMainWindow class with your own when the UI is instantiated. This means you can subclass QMainWindow and override functions like closeEvent, while still designing the window in Qt Designer. See the BLACSWindow class in pythonlib/BLACS/main.pyw for an example implementation

See the BLACSWindow class in pythonlib/BLACS/main.pyw for an example implementation

values.message:
Added some code (that I got from the internet, it is licensed under the MIT license) that modifies the behaviour of the QUiLoader

This code allows you to create the "QMainWindow" in Qt Designer, but override the QMainWindow class with your own when the UI is instantiated. This means you can subclass QMainWindow and override functions like closeEvent, while still designing the window in Qt Designer. See the BLACSWindow class in pythonlib/BLACS/main.pyw for an example implementation

message.raw:
Added ability to force relayout of objects (seemed to need to do this to make DDS channels show up for the novatechDDS9m BLACS tab)
Fixed some bugs in ddsoutput widget which prevented all freq/amp/phase widgets from being displayed (an exception was always raised)
